sections.text:
Carbon isotope measurements have been made on bulk carbonate and organic matter in three sections across the Cenomanian–
Turonian boundary. The stratigraphy records the positive carbon isotopic excursion that is associated with the major oceanic
anoxic event (OAE2). Comparison of TOC and isotopic data in sections from a range of different environments suggests that the
positive excursion is a response to increased burial of organic matter in the deep ocean. The lack of coupled negative shifts in y13Corg and y 13Ccarb records at the onset of OAE2 does not support a causal role for volcanism or methane hydrate dissociation. D 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: ocean anoxic events; OAE2; 13-C; Cenomanian Turonian boundary; Western Interior Seaway

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The Cretaceous period (~140–65 Ma) was characterized by bgreenhouseQ conditions (elevated pCO2), a lack of extensive polar ice caps, low latitudinal temper-
ature gradients, and high sea level (Barron and Wash-
ington, 1982; Berner et al., 1983;Arthur et al., 1985;Haq
et al., 1987; Arthur et al., 1988; Weissert, 1989; Caldeira
and Rampino, 1991; Wilson and Norris, 2001; Norris et
al., 2002). Periodic deposition of organic carbon (Corg)-

rich black shales, dark gray to black laminated carbona-
ceous mudrocks, took place during oceanic anoxic
events (OAEs) (e.g., Schlanger and Jenkyns, 1976;
Jenkyns, 1980; Arthur et al., 1990; Bralower et al., 1993;
Erbacher et al., 1996; Erba et al., 2004). These rocks
were deposited in epicontinental seaways, on continental
margins, and in the deep ocean (e.g., Ryan and Cita,
1977; Arthur and Schlanger, 1979). Possible factors
responsible for deposition of black shales include a
combination of high sea-level, warm climate, sluggish
ocean circulation, and high organic productivity (e.g.,
Arthur et al., 1984; Arthur et al., 1987).
The Cenomanian–Turonian boundary (CTB) event
(OAE2) at 93.5 Ma spanned ~600,000 years and led to
deposition of Corg-rich sediments on a global basis (e.g., Schlanger and Jenkyns, 1976; Jenkyns, 1980;
Hilbrecht, 1986; Schlanger et al., 1987; Arthur et al.,
1988; Pratt et al., 1993; Hasegawa, 1995). This
widespread distribution of Corg-rich sediments is evidenced by a prominent, positive C-isotope excur-
sion near the CTB in a number of sections measured on the calcium carbonate (y13Ccarb; Scholle and Arthur, 1980; Schlanger et al., 1987; Jarvis et al., 1988; Gale et
al., 1993; Paul et al., 1999; Tsikos et al., 2004) and the organic matter fraction (y13Corg; Pratt and Threlkeld, 1984; Pratt, 1985; Arthur et al., 1988; Hasegawa,
1997; Hasegawa, 2003; Hasegawa et al., 2003). This
excursion, which is used as a relative dating technique, is thought to reflect the widespread removal of 12C-
enriched organic matter in marine sediments.
Using examples of modern environments where
Corg-rich sediments are found, several theories have been proposed for the origin of OAEs (e.g., Arthur et
al., 1984; Bralower and Thierstein, 1987; Schlanger et
al., 1987; Weissert, 1989). In areas of high phytoplank-
ton productivity, fluxes of marine Corg are high and dissolved oxygen in the deepest portions of the water
column is depleted (e.g., Reimers, 1982; Pedersen and
Calvert, 1990). Alternatively, ocean anoxia and Corgrich sediments are found in areas of the ocean where
stratification is increased by reduced mixing and/or
high-density contrasts between different water masses
(e.g., Berry and Wilde, 1978; Brass et al., 1982).
Recently, however, research has focused on two
more dynamic triggers for OAEs. Active volcanism
may have directly or indirectly initiated OAEs (e.g.,
Vogt, 1989; Larson, 1991; Arthur et al., 1991; Bralower
et al., 1994; Erba, 1994; Sinton and Duncan, 1997;
Larson and Erba, 1999; Leckie et al., 2002; Erba et al.,
2004). Submarine volcanism releases reduced com-
pounds (sulfides and metals) that have the potential to
consume dissolved oxygen in seawater (Sinton and
Duncan, 1997). Hydrothermal Fe may act as a micro-
nutrient in surface waters, stimulating primary produc-
tivity and reducing deep-water oxygenation (Vogt,
1989; Sinton and Duncan, 1997; Leckie et al., 2002). In
the case of OAE2, contemporaneous ocean plateau
formation in the Caribbean may have led to widespread
ocean anoxia or dysoxia (Sinton and Duncan, 1997;
Kerr, 1998; Snow et al., in press).
There is growing evidence that dissociation of
biogenic methane hydrate in bottom waters along
continental margins may have initiated certain OAEs
(see summary in Jenkyns, 2003). Although the physical
and chemical effects of this dissociation are not well
understood, the oxidation of the dissociated methane to
CO2 could rapidly consume oxygen in deepwaters. Input of methane and CO2 to the atmosphere would also cause warming (e.g., Dickens et al., 1995); if this warming
signal were transferred via downwelling to deep waters
(i.e., warm saline deep water), it would have acted as a
positive feedback, amplifying anoxic conditions.
The purported causes of OAEs can be identified by
changes in the carbon isotopic ratios of CaCO3 and Corg. In the Toarcian (Early Jurassic) and early Aptian OAEs, an abrupt and large negative carbon isotopic
shift lies immediately below or at the base of the
positive carbon isotope excursion (Hesselbo et al.,
2000; Jahren et al., 2001; Beerling et al., 2002). Mantle-derived CO2 is a source of light carbon (y 13C about 6x). As CO2 enters the ocean–atmosphere system through volcanism, negative shifts are recorded in y13C. Negative shifts can also theoretically result from introduction of hydrate methane (y13C value about 60x) into the system from dissociation. Distinguishing between the various sources of light
carbon requires accurate records of the isotopic signals
as well as precise time control to establish the rates of
response (e.g., Dickens et al., 1997; Kump and Arthur,
1999; Norris and Röhl, 1999). The magnitude and rate
of introduction of light carbon has been used as
evidence for a hydrate trigger for the Toarcian OAE
(Hesselbo et al., 2000) and early Aptian OAE1a
(Jahren et al., 2001; Beerling et al., 2002). A logical
question is whether all OAEs had such a trigger.
Until recently few CTB sections had been studied in
sufficient resolution to address whether a transient
negative carbon isotope shift exists. Most published
records (Scholle and Arthur, 1980; Pratt, 1985; Arthur
et al., 1988; Jarvis et al., 1988) showed gradually
increasing carbon isotope values at the base of the
positive excursion without a negative shift. The y13Ccarb record of Scott et al. (1998) from the Bounds Core in Kansas contains a ~6x negative shift slightly above the base of the positive isotope excursion. This shift is not observed in y13Corg although the resolution of the y13Corg curve is lower than that of y 13Ccarb. Recently, Tsikos et al. (2004) carried out high-
resolution sampling of CTB sections from England,
Italy, andMorocco, illustrating a detailed series of steps
during the onset and recovery of the OAE2 positive
carbon isotope excursion. None of the records show a
negative isotope event at the onset of the positive
excursion that would be compatible with a volcanic
(i.e., Caribbean) or methane hydrate trigger. Although
these sections appear to be complete, and those from
England and Morocco are relatively expanded, it is
possible that condensed intervals or unconformities
have removed the key part of the isotope excursion.
Thus, additional isotope stratigraphies are required to
resolve whether a negative excursion is present at the
base of OAE2.
In this study, isotopic investigations of classic CTB
sections from the Western Interior Seaway (WIS),
including the stratotype section in the Rock Canyon
Anticline near Pueblo (Pratt and Threlkeld, 1984; Pratt,
1985) and a section near Cuba, Kansas, were done at
sufficient stratigraphic resolution to observe transient
events such as a potential negative isotope excursion.
In addition, an expanded CTB section in a borehole
from New Jersey was investigated at high resolution to
determine the detailed structure of the onset of the carbon isotopic excursion. In all sequences, y13Corg and y13Ccarb were analyzed to fully constrain the response of carbon reservoirs at the onset of OAE2.

sections.heading: 2.1. The Western Interior basin
sections.text:
The global transgression of the Late Cretaceous led
to the formation of extensive epicontinental seaways
(e.g., Hancock and Kauffman, 1979). The CTB lies
within the transgressive part of a third-order eustatic
cycle that culminated in an early Turonian highstand,
the highest sea level of the Mesozoic era (Williams
and Stelck, 1975; Haq et al., 1987).
The Western Interior Seaway (WIS) of North
America extended some 6000 km from the Gulf of
Mexico to the Arctic close to the CTB (Leckie et al.,
1998) (Fig. 1). At this time, the seaway was about
2000 km wide and about 500 m deep (Hay et al.,
1993). The WIS was bounded by the Sevier High-
lands to the west and the low relief, stable craton to
the east (Leckie et al., 1998). The complex inter-
actions between less dense, warm surface waters
originating in the Gulf of Mexico and dense, cold
and brackish waters from the Arctic exerted a strong
control of depositional patterns (Leckie et al., 1998).
For example, Kauffman (1988) postulated that strat-
ification and anoxia occurred when southern waters
were superposed on northern waters.
The CTB in the WIS lies within the Bridge Creek
Limestone Member of the Greenhorn Formation just
above the Hartland Shale Member of the same
formation (e.g., Kauffman and Pratt, 1985). The Bridge
Creek Limestone at Rock Canyon consists of cyclically
alternating pelagic carbonates (chalk and limestone)
and more Corg-rich beds (marlstone and calcareous shale) (Kauffman, 1977; Barron et al., 1985; Hattin,
1985; Kauffman, 1985; Elder et al., 1994). The
Hartland Shale is a homogeneous, generally more
TOC-rich unit (Sageman, 1985; Pratt, 1985).
The Cuba section in northern-central Kansas is
about 600 km east of the Rock Canyon section. This
includes the Jetmore Chalk and Pfeifer Shale Mem-
bers of the Greenhorn Formation (Hattin, 1975) that
are dominated by marlstone and calcareous shale. The
lithologic cyclicity observed at Rock Canyon is
virtually absent (Figs. 2 and 3).

sections.heading: 2.2. New Jersey coastal plain
sections.text:
The New Jersey coastal plain has been a passive
margin since the Early Jurassic, the locus of several
hundreds of meters of sediment accumulation. The
Bass River borehole (Fig. 1) drilled during Ocean
Drilling Program Leg 174AX shows a clear record of
sea-level fluctuation (Miller et al., 1998; Sugarman et
al., 1999). The Bass River Sequence spans the CTB
and is dominated by dark gray silty clay at the base,
grading upward into sandy clay (Fig. 4). Sedimenta-
tion rates are relatively high (~30 m/m.y.).

sections.heading: 2.3. Sampling procedures
sections.text:
Samples were collected at high resolution in all
sections.At Cuba, continuous sampleswere collected in
large blocks from the outcrop between the HL-2 and
HL-3 bentonite marker beds (283–350 cm). These
samples were later separated at ~1–2-cm intervals.
Samples were collected about every 10 cm in the lower
270 cmof section belowHL-2 (0–270 cm) and for about
100 cm above HL-3 (367–477 cm). The upper ~300 cm
of section (477–767 cm) was sampled every 50 cm.
At Rock Canyon, samples were collected every 1–
4 cm between the HL-2 and HL-3 bentonites (164–
305 cm). Samples were collected every ~10 cm in the
150 cm of section below HL-2 (0–150 cm) and in the
~90 cm above HL-3 (330–410 cm). The lowermost
~350 cm and uppermost 610 cm of section (410–1020
cm) was sampled every 50 cm. All samples are
referenced to 0 cm at the base of the lowermost
limestone level which lies at the base of the Bridge
Creek Limestone; thus, samples below 0 cm belong to
the Hartland Shale.
In the Bass River borehole, samples were taken
every 6 in. (15 cm) throughout the lower portion of
the core (1950–1941 ft). Samples were taken every
2.5 in. (6 cm) across the CTB (1941.0–1930.4 ft).
Samples were taken every 18 in. (45 cm) in the upper
portion of the core (1930.4–1900 ft).

sections.heading: 2.4. Analytical methods
sections.text:
Surfaces of samples were cleaned with buffered
water and dried. Samples were then crushed into a
very fine powder by hand with a mortar and pestle.
Percent CaCO3 and total organic carbon (TOC) were analyzed in a UIC CO2 gas coulometer in the Department of Geological Sciences at the University
of North Carolina, Chapel Hill (UNC-CH). Analytical precision was F1.5% for both measurements. Stable carbon isotope ratios were determined on the
Corg and CaCO3 fractions. Analysis of the Corg fraction was performed in the Department ofMarine Sciences at
UNC-CH; the lowermost nine samples from Rock
Canyon were analyzed in the Department of Soil
Science at University of California, Davis (UCD). For
carbon-isotope analysis of the organic carbon, about 2
g of powdered sample was treated with ~2N hydro-
chloric acid for about 48 h to dissolve carbonate
minerals. The samples were then rinsed three times
with deionized water in a centrifuge. These carbonatefree samples were then stored in an oven at ~60 8C prior to analysis. At UNC-CH, a Carlo Erba 1500 Elemental
Analyzer (EA) coupled with a conflow interface was
used to combust the organic matter in the samples. The
resulting carbon dioxide gas was fed into a Finnigan
MAT 252 stable isotope mass spectrometer for isotope
analysis. Samples were compared to the PDB standard.
Standards were run about every five samples to ensure accuracy. At UCD, y13C analysis was carried out on an Isoprime isotope ratio mass spectrometer interfaced to a Carlo Erba elemental analyzer. Precision is F0.15x for analyses at UNC-CH and UCD.
Carbon isotope analysis of the carbonate fraction
was performed in the Stable Isotope Laboratory in the
Department of Geological Sciences at Rutgers Uni-
versity. A VG Prism II mass spectrometer with an
IsoCarb automated carbonate prep system was used.
Samples are reported relative to the VPDB standard.
Samples were reacted in 100% phosphoric acid at 90 8C for 10 min. Each run of ~30 samples was followed by at least three standards. Precision is F0.15x. All data are archived at the World Data Center-A for
Paleoclimatology.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Carbon isotopes
sections.text:
The y13C values of carbonate (y13Ccarb) and organic carbon (y13Corg) correlate for much of the CTB interval (Fig. 2). Both y13C curves record OAE 2 by a positive excursion. The y13Ccarb values of samples
from 0- to 200-cm range from 0.21x to 2.0x (Fig. 2; Table 1). The onset of the positive excursion lies at 200 cm, y13Ccarb values increase rapidly from 0.95x to 4.34x at 240 cm, then decrease slightly but remain generally above 2x to ~450 cm. A large ( 5.5x) shift defined by a single, low y13Ccarb value occurs at 270 cm (uppermost Cenomanian) (Fig. 2). The y13Ccarb values of samples from 450 to 767 cm are mostly slightly less than ~2.0x.
In the lowermost 200 cm of the section, y13Corg values of samples are generally low and increase gradually from 28.02x to 26.62x (Fig. 2; Table 1). At 200 cm, y13Corg values increase rapidly to 22.73x at 240 cm. Throughout the positive excursion, y13Corg values remain above 24.69x. The y13Corg values decrease from 23.29x to about 26x (higher than pre-excursion values) between ~360 and 767 cm. The abrupt, negative shift in y13Ccarb at 270 cm is not observed in y 13Corg (Fig. 2).

sections.heading: 3.1.2. TOC and CaCO3 contents
sections.text:
TOC contents of samples range up to 9.7%, and
show large variations especially in the intensively
sampled middle part of the section near the CTB (Fig.
2; Table 1). Mean and standard deviation for TOC for
the whole section are 3.59% and 2.07%, respectively.
TOC contents are low (b1.5%) from 210 cm to 286
cm, then increase to ~7.6% at 289 cm. Large
fluctuations in TOC are observed in samples between
300 cm and 370 cm, where TOC contents range from
0.4% to 9.7% (mean=3.8%). TOC contents generally
decrease in the upper part of the section above 370
cm. Mean values in this interval are 3.16%.
CaCO3 contents of samples are generally high (mean=67.6%, standard deviation=14.64%), with
large fluctuations that commonly oppose trends in
TOC. For example, large variations of up to 40% occur
over just a few centimeters between 300 and 370 cm
nearly inverse to the trends in TOC. This relationship
has been observed and discussed by previous workers
(e.g., Pratt, 1984; Barron et al., 1985). In other
intervals, TOC and CaCO3 show a positive correlation.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Carbon isotopes
sections.text:
y13Ccarb values of samples are relatively constant at ~1x in the Hartland Shale between 360 cm and 0
cm, then fluctuate significantly between 1.5x and 4.0x in the lower part of the Bridge Creek Limestone between 0 cm and 212 cm. Above 212 cm, variation decreases and y13Ccarb values generally increase from about 1.5x to 3.29x at 273 cm, then generally decrease gradually above that point (Fig. 3; Table 2). The y13Corg curve shows clearer stratigraphic trends with generally smaller fluctuations. Between 30 cm and 50 cm, y13Corg values increase sharply (from 26.26x to 22.27x), marking the onset of the positive excursion (Fig. 3). One highly negative shift of ~4.9x occurs between 50 cm and 164 cm. y13Corg values of samples are generally level near 23x between 164 cm and 470 cm, then decrease to
25.86x at 670 cm. The high-resolution y13Corg curve shows the same general trends as the y13Corg curve generated by Pratt (1985) that was supplemented with additional
data by Arthur et al. (1988). Although biostratig-
raphy is exclusive to the outcrop section (Leckie,
1985; Watkins, 1985; Bralower, 1988), diagnostic
marker beds combined with prominent features in the y13Corg record allow correlation between sections. For example, the A and C points from Pratt
(1985) lie at ~50 cm and ~400 cm, respectively. However, the high-resolution y13Corg record shows variability not observed by Pratt (1985) and Arthur
et al. (1988) and point B (Pratt, 1985) is difficult to identify. The ~4.9x negative shift in y13Corg lies directly above point A. Trends in y13Ccarb values are similar to those in Pratt (1985) but fluctuations
observed here in the lower part of the Bridge Creek
Limestone are significantly larger. The one exception is a 3x shift in y13Ccarb observed at ~18 m in Pratt (1985) that appears to correlate to the negative shift in y13Corg and y 13Ccarb at 50 cm in this study (Fig. 3).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. TOC and CaCO3 contents
sections.text:
Samples from the Hartland Shale generally have
higher TOC contents than those from the Bridge
Creek (Pratt, 1985; Pratt et al., 1993). TOC is
relatively low throughout the Bridge Creek section
(mean=0.7%; standard deviation=0.7%) (Fig. 3). The
highest TOC contents (between 2.6% and 3.9%)
correspond to the interval between 340 and 390 cm
(Fig. 3; Table 2). CaCO3 contents are high (mean=64.8%; standard deviation=17.0%) and gen-

al. (1999).
Scanning Electron Micrograph (SEM) images were
taken of some of the benthic foraminifera used for
analysis in this study. The chambers of foraminifera in
samples recording the highly negative isotope values
near 1940 ft are often filled with secondary calcite
(Fig. 5). The non-excursion specimens show better
preservation and are less diagenetically altered.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
The long-term positive excursion in y13C at the CTB is thought to result from large-scale burial of 12C-enriched organic matter during OAE2 (e.g.,
Scholle and Arthur, 1980; Schlanger et al., 1987;
Arthur et al., 1988). Buried organic matter is both
marine and terrestrial in origin (e.g., Hasegawa et al.,
2003). However, the relationship between the timing
of the positive isotope excursion and the deposition of
organic matter is complex. For example, in the WIS
sections organic matter contents and accumulation
rates actually decrease at the onset, then increase in the
middle of the positive isotope excursion (Figs. 2 and
3) (Pratt, 1984, 1985; Schlanger et al., 1987). Tsikos et
al. (2004) presented detailed carbon isotope and TOC
data from Tarfaya, Morocco that showed consistently
high TOC values several meters above and below the
base of the positive isotope excursion. A much clearer relationship between TOC and y13C is observed in the Bottaccione section of Umbria, Italy, where the base
of the carbonaceous Bonarelli horizon lies at the onset
of the positive carbon isotope excursion (Tsikos et al.,
2004). The ultimate cause of the positive carbon
isotope excursion may involve an increase in the
proportion of carbon buried as organic matter rather
than biogenic carbonate (e.g., Kump and Arthur,
1999) as a result of increased burial rates of organic
matter in pelagic locations, while negligible changes
in Corg burial rates occurred in epicontinental regions.
There has been considerable discussion in the
literature about the interpretation of small features in
carbon isotope stratigraphies. Pratt (1985) and Pratt
and Threlkeld (1984) were the first to attempt detailed correlation of changes on the order of 0.5–1x in sections from WIS. Menegatti et al. (1998) used
similar terminology for Aptian carbon isotope varia-
tions in sections from Tethys and their results were
applied by Bralower et al. (1999) in Mexican sections
and Herrle et al. (2003) in sections from southern
France. The investigation of Tsikos et al. (2004)
advanced our understanding of the biostratigraphy
and chemostratigraphy of the CTB interval. The highresolution y13Corg records from Eastbourne and Tarfaya show remarkable similarity to those from
Cuba and Rock Canyon (Fig. 6). We have adapted the
terminology of Pratt (1985) to correlate features in all
of the sections. An intriguing question that cannot be
addressed at this time given the lack of more detailed
chemical data concerns the significance of these small
changes. Nonetheless, the small features in carbon
isotope stratigraphy have the potential to allow high-
resolution correlation between CTB sections that
cannot be achieved using other techniques. The Bass River y13Corg curve does not show the same features (Fig. 4) possibly because sedimentation rates are much
higher in this section (Sugarman et al., 1999) and the
investigated interval lies close to the CTB.
Previous investigations have noted that the magnitude of the excursion in y13Corg (Dy 13Corg) is nearly double (~4x) that of the excursion in y13Ccarb (Dy13Ccarb) (~2x) (Arthur et al., 1988; Hayes et al., 1989; Freeman and Hayes, 1992). Such differences
have been explained by increased pCO2 (Arthur et al., 1988; Kump and Arthur, 1999), and changes in the
species composition of primary producers and the
nature of food chains (Hayes et al., 1989). Data
collected here support the general conclusion that Dy13Corg exceeds Dy 13Ccarb. However, differences in Dy13Corg and Dy 13Ccarb at Cuba and Bass River appear less than in previous investigations. At Cuba Dy13Corg and Dy 13Ccarb values are ~4.5x and ~3.2x, respectively (Fig. 2), while at Bass River, Dy13Corg is only ~1.5x (Fig. 4). Although the change in y13Ccarb at Bass River cannot be determined due to diagenetic
alteration, the low Dy13Corg is consistent with conclusions from Cuba. Studies of Eastbourne and
Tarfaya sections by Tsikos et al. (2004) also showed smaller differences between Dy13Corg and Dy 13Ccarb values than in previous investigations (Arthur et al.,
1988; Hayes et al., 1989).
The ultimate causes of OAE2 remain elusive.
Increases in primary production, water column strat-
ification, and submarine volcanism have been pro-
posed as triggers (Arthur et al., 1987; Leckie et al.,
1998; Sinton and Duncan, 1997; Sinton et al., 1998). In
addition, for other OAEs, dissociation of methane
hydrate has been invoked as a casual mechanism (e.g.,
Hesselbo et al., 2000; Jahren et al., 2001; Beerling et
al., 2002), and this alternative must be considered for
OAE2. Volcanism and hydrate dissociation are attrac-
tive hypotheses because these processes should,
theoretically at least, perturb climate as well as ocean
chemistry. For example, dissociation of large quantities
of methane hydrates in oceanic bottomwaters would be
followed by oxidation of the gas to CO2 in the ocean and/or atmosphere. Oxidation of sufficient methane in
the ocean could result in widespread anoxia (e.g.,
Hesselbo et al., 2000). Extensive submarine hydro-
thermal activity might release large quantities of
micronutrients such as iron into the ocean stimulating
productivity (e.g., Sinton and Duncan, 1997).
Both volcanic and hydrate triggers have draw-
backs, however. For example, there is some doubt that
hydrate would have been stable in bottom waters in the late Cenomanian, at close to peak bgreenhouseQ temperatures (i.e., Huber et al., 1995, 2002). There is
also some disagreement of the age of the Caribbean
LIP and its correlation with OAE2. Decreasing
strontium isotope values that might correspond to
the Caribbean LIP lie somewhat above OAE2
(Bralower et al., 1997; Jones and Jenkyns, 2001;
McArthur et al., 2001). However, ages of basalt from
drillsites and obducted terranes extend back to 93.5
Ma (Sinton et al., 1998; Snow et al., in press) and thus
overlap with OAE2. Moreover, metal anomalies,
possible signals of hydrothermal anomalies are found
in strata corresponding to the carbon isotope excur-
sion at Rock Canyon (Snow et al., in press) and other
sections from the WIS (Orth et al., 1993). Thus a
volcanic signal could realistically lie within the
resulting carbon isotopic records.
Any changes in the flux of mantle CO2 or dissociation of hydrate methane would change the
isotopic ratios of inorganic (i.e., biogenic calcite) and
organic carbon in oceanic reservoirs. Likewise, any
mechanism that alters the proportion of carbon buried
as organic matter and carbonate would change the
isotopic ratios of reactive oceanic and atmospheric
carbon. Diagenesis, on the other hand, is more likely
to alter the isotopic signal of sedimentary carbonates
and organic matter in a different fashion. Typically, y13Ccarb are more susceptible to alteration during burial (e.g., Anderson and Arthur, 1983; Pratt, 1985); however, y13Corg values could be altered significantly by outcrop weathering. The focus of the high-
resolution studies of outcrop and core sections is to
determine whether negative isotope anomalies from
volcanic sources (i.e., Caribbean LIP) or methane
hydrate dissociation occur at the CTB.
Large, abrupt negative shifts in y13Ccarb observed in the Bass River, Cuba, and Rock Canyon sections
are generally not found in y13Corg: (1) benthic foraminifera Gavelinella and Epistomina from Bass River show abrupt 8x and 5x negative excursions, respectively, in the 1939–1941-ft interval (Fig. 4). The y13Corg curve does not show any significant changes in the equivalent interval. Moreover, SEM
images show sparry calcite infilling foraminiferal
chambers in the intervals with highly negative y13Ccarb values (Fig. 5). Specimens observed in samples from above and below the y13Ccarb excursion interval, while poorly preserved, show less evidence
of recrystallization and little chamber infilling. (2) A
5x shift in the y13Ccarb at the 270-cm level in the Cuba section does not correspond to changes in y13Corg values (Fig. 2). (3) The y 13Ccarb curve at Rock Canyon shows large fluctuations in the lower 220 cm
of section (Fig. 3). This fluctuation becomes significant in the OAE interval. The y13Corg data show one significant excursion in the lower 220 cm of section.
Changes in the type of organic matter preserved within the rock can affect the y13Corg signature. RockEval analysis of samples from the lower 220 cm
of the Rock Canyon section indicate that organicmatter
is both marine and terrestrial in origin, but no
significant variations that could result in changes in y13Corg values are found (Michael Arthur, personal communication, 2002). The y13Ccarb fluctuations in the lower 220 cm of section correspond to lithologic cycles
in the Rock Canyon outcrop. The relationship between y13Ccarb and%CaCO3 clearly shows lithologic control. For example, limestone samples (higher CaCO3 content) generally have lower y13Ccarb values than marl and shale samples (lower CaCO3 content). However, a relationship between lithology and y13Corg is not apparent. Our y13Corg and y 13Ccarb curves generally replicate data from the Pueblo core in Pratt (1985) and
Arthur et al. (1988), but at higher resolution. The one
major difference, the significant negative shift in y13Corg between 50 cm and 164 cm, could result from oxidation of organic matter in the outcrop samples.
We conclude that oxidation of organic matter (y13C~ 25x) and incorporation of light carbon into recrystallized calcium carbonate accounts for abrupt, negative shifts in the y13Ccarb record at Rock Canyon and Cuba, and the benthic foraminiferal y13Ccarb record in the Bass River borehole. A similar mechanism is probable for the negative shift in y13Ccarb observed by Scott et al. (1998) in the Bounds core.
The absence of correlative shifts in y13Corg and y13Ccarb in the three sections investigated as well as those studied by Hasegawa et al. (2003) and Tsikos et
al. (2004) does not support hydrate dissociation or
volcanism as a trigger for OAE2. However, Snow et
al. (in press) found enrichments of trace elements near
the base of OAE2 in several sections including Rock
Canyon, interpret them as a signature of Caribbean
volcanism, and suggest that volcanism played a direct
role in initiating OAE2. It is possible that input of
mantle CO2 at the onset of the Caribbean eruptions was insufficient to cause a signal in marine carbon
reservoirs or that such a signal was obscured by burial
of large quantities of organic matter in the deep ocean
at the onset of OAE2.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
High-resolution carbon isotope stratigraphy of
three sections across the base of OAE2 near the
Cenomanian–Turonian boundary shows the well-
documented positive excursion. Comparison with
TOC data suggests that the carbon isotopic signal
is driven by changes in the burial rates of organic
matter in the deep ocean rather than in shallow marine locations. Small (0.5–1.0x) changes in y13Corg can be correlated between sections allowing for higher resolution correlation than available using traditional biostratigraphy. Coupled y13Corg and y13Ccarb records do not support input of mantle CO2 or dissociation of methane hydrate at the onset of the event. Thus, our data do not support a
volcanic or hydrate trigger for OAE2. It is possible
that the mantle carbon signal corresponding to the
Caribbean LIP was masked by the burial of organic
matter at the onset of OAE2.

abstractText: Carbon isotope measurements have been made on bulk carbonate and organic matter in three sections across the Cenomanian– Turonian boundary. The stratigraphy records the positive carbon isotopic excursion that is associated with the major oceanic anoxic event (OAE2). Comparison of TOC and isotopic data in sections from a range of different environments suggests that the positive excursion is a response to increased burial of organic matter in the deep ocean. The lack of coupled negative shifts in yCorg and y Ccarb records at the onset of OAE2 does not support a causal role for volcanism or methane hydrate dissociation. D 2005 Elsevier B.V.
